intro: Hirtella scandens, commonly known as the hairy mistletoe, is a parasitic plant belonging to the family Viscaraceae. It attaches itself to the branches of host trees, primarily in tropical and subtropical regions. The plant produces small, white or greenish flowers and red, fleshy berries that are often consumed by birds. Its leaves are usually hairy, giving it its common name, and it plays a role in the ecological interactions of its habitat. Hirtella scandens is often found in the canopy of forests, contributing to the biodiversity of its ecosystem.
